WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FAMILIES EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. J. H. Clarke
Address: 2279 Athol St., Regina, Sask.
Birthplace: Near London, Ontario.

1. IMMIGRATORY JURISDICTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1910
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Eastview, Sask.
   Where had you been living before that? Gray, Sask.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Twenty-five to twenty-five
   How far was it to your nearest store? One mile
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, oatmeal, salt, tea, coffee, dried fruits, rice, tapioca, molasses, syrup, cheese, crackers, canned tomatoes, apples.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? "York River," "Lake of the Woods Milling Co.," "Lodi," "Robin Hood"
   In what quantities did you buy it? Five hundred pounds
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
   How much did you use Graham flour? Very little
   Whole wheat flour? Very little
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? _______ What year? _______
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Yes, also for flour, whole wheat? Farina? About the same as oatmeal
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   How did you grind it?

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) River, 9 miles, Luke & Miller's dugout, 7 miles, Salt Springs.

How far was this water from your home? 8 miles, 6 miles, 2 miles.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Tank, Barrels.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

I had a water system in our new home in 1928. Hot & cold running water. But the supply was artificial. The cement cisterns were kept filled by hauling water in barrels and cleaned & filled twice a year.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Inserted in the wooden boxes found in the old-fashioned bags, which have replaced the old brown paper bags. All the hardboard boxes replaced the old heavy brown cardboard containers a few years ago.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - 1910, Bacon and eggs, fruit, potatoes, oatmeal, milk - cream, syrup, bread and butter, coffee.

Dinner - 1910, Roast Beef, Brown Gravy, Potatoes, vegetables, pickles, pie, bread and butter, tea, milk.

Supper - 1910, Cold Meat, Potato Cakes, Macaroni Cheese, United Fruit Cake and Tea, milk.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? _________________. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

As I remember the Christmas dinner of the early days, they were much the same as today. Turkey or ham, gravy, mashed potatoes & turnips, plum pudding, and mince pie, tea, coffee, milk, orange nuts candy.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We always had an abundance with the exception of 1931 when we did not produce enough green vegetables to feed the baby chicks. However our relatives in Northern Saskatchewan shipped us green vegetables once a week while they were obtainable. Then Eastern Canada sent fruits & vegetables through the United Church by railroad cars, and everyone got a share. B.C. apples were cheap & plentiful that fall.

Dinner - 1910, Baked Ham, Potatoes, Macaroni, Gravy

That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in autumn? Yes or No?

18. What was the name of the first Christmas tree you had? How did you get it?

19. How old were you when you started to almost starve? How long did it last?

20. Abundance with the exception of 1931.

In a diet poor for nature, we may still grow abundant crops.

If fact this family thrived, prospered and achieved a comfortable standard of living.

And finally, vegetables grown through the times of war, peace and prosperity.

Poveshell, Iowa, built covered well hall.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

They are more prepared foods today or compared with the early days. The meats, fish, and cured, canned, and the vegetables and fruits. The bread and butter is not longer made at home. The guests and house refrigerator right in the kitchen change everything.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

During the Depression years we did can our meat and vegetables and bake our bread and churn our butter ($36 - $38) but the change has been gradually working up to the present day. We have been over 25 years.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

These things are gone forever! The fruit cellar was filled with canned supplies & boxes of apples. The barrels done in brine. The ten gallon stone jars of canned fruit. The shelves of canned fruit, meat and vegetables. The shelves of preserves jams and jellies. A big box of dried apples. Stone jars of eggs in water-glass. Stone jars of butter packed for winter months. I made the ground rolls and put myself them in a box that would carry an egg. The sausage. We bought the chickens and stuffed them with the ground pork properly seasoned and preserved and stored in glass jars. Had to this a big wash boiler of crushed brown sugar & homemade bread and do a pretty good place to store in for the winter. Mrs. J. W. Clarke
